source.name: City of Columbus Department of Public Service
source.notes: Based on official City of Columbus recycling guidelines and SWACO (Solid Waste Authority of Central Ohio) resources. 99% recycling recovery rate at Rumpke facility.

materials.name: Cardboard and corrugated boxes
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, styrofoam, air pillows)
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Cardboard is one of the most valuable recyclables
Columbus achieves 99% recovery rate through Rumpke
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food
Don't leave packing materials inside boxes
Don't include wax-coated cardboard

materials.name: Paper (office, printer, notebook)
instructions: Place loose in blue recycling cart
Shredded paper: place inside a paper bag, then in cart
notes: Staples and paper clips are OK — removed during processing
Envelopes with plastic windows are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include wet or soiled paper
Don't include paper towels or tissues

materials.name: Newspapers, magazines, and catalogs
instructions: Place loose in blue recycling cart
Glossy paper is accepted
No need to remove staples
notes: All types of printed paper are accepted in Columbus recycling
Inserts and advertising circulars are included
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags
Don't include wet or moldy paper

materials.name: Mail, envelopes, and junk mail
instructions: Place in blue recycling cart
Window envelopes are accepted — no need to remove plastic windows
notes: Greeting cards without glitter or metallic decorations are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include greeting cards with glitter — the glitter contaminates recycling
Don't include padded/bubble mailers — those go in trash

materials.name: Cereal boxes and paperboard
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove plastic liners
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Thin paperboard/chipboard is recyclable in Columbus
Part of the general paper category
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag/liner
Don't include boxes heavily soiled with food

materials.name: Carton containers (milk, juice, broth)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Both refrigerated (gable-top) and shelf-stable (aseptic/Tetra Pak) cartons are accepted
Columbus specifically lists carton containers as accepted
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons — the 3D shape helps sorting machines identify them
Don't confuse with juice pouches (Capri Sun) — those go in trash

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle lids with metal cans)
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: All colors of glass are accepted in Columbus
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, ceramics, or drinking glasses
Don't include Pyrex or heat-resistant glass

materials.name: Metal cans (aluminum, steel, tin)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place loose in blue recycling cart
notes: Columbus accepts both aluminum and steel/tin cans
Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue
Don't crush cans — leave intact for sorting

materials.name: Metal cups and containers
instructions: Empty and clean
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Columbus specifically lists metal cups as accepted recyclables
commonMistakes: Don't include small metal items like paper clips or staples loose — they fall through screens

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Columbus accepts all plastic bottles
No need to sort by resin number
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with significant residue
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic containers (tubs, clamshells)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Columbus accepts rigid plastic containers of all types
Processed at Rumpke with 99% recovery rate
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with food residue
Don't include flexible plastic bags or film

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do not puncture
Remove plastic cap
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans are safe for recycling
The metal can itself is recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cans that still have contents — they're hazardous
Don't puncture cans

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in blue recycling cart
Can be used to contain shredded paper
notes: Paper bags are recyclable and compostable
commonMistakes: Don't include paper bags contaminated with grease or food

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate books in good condition to Columbus Metropolitan Library or thrift stores
Damaged books: remove hardcovers and recycle the paper pages
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Books can be dropped off at SWACO for recycling
Donation is always preferred over recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw away books that could be donated

materials.name: Clean aluminum foil
instructions: Must be clean and free of food residue
Ball up small pieces into a larger ball (golf-ball size minimum)
Place in blue recycling cart
notes: Only clean aluminum foil is recyclable — food-contaminated foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy or food-covered foil
Don't put small scraps loose — ball them up

materials.name: Plastic bags, wraps, and film
instructions: Place in trash cart
Many Kroger and Walmart stores accept clean plastic bags for recycling
Never place in the blue recycling cart
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in Columbus recycling
They tangle in sorting machinery at the Rumpke facility
commonMistakes: NEVER bag recyclables in plastic bags
Don't put any plastic film in the blue cart

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene foam
instructions: Do NOT place in blue recycling cart
Place in trash cart for curbside disposal
Styrofoam packing (clean, white block EPS) can be taken to SWACO Recycling Center
notes: Curbside: styrofoam goes in trash
Exception: SWACO Recycling Center at 2566 Jackson Pike accepts clean expanded polystyrene packaging
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the blue recycling cart
Don't include food-contaminated styrofoam at SWACO — only clean packing foam

materials.name: Food waste and scraps
instructions: Place in trash cart
Bag food waste to contain odor
Columbus does not have curbside composting
notes: Food waste is not accepted in Columbus recycling
Consider home composting for fruit/vegetable scraps
commonMistakes: Never put food waste in the recycling cart

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Columbus provides separate yard waste collection seasonally
Place in approved yard waste bags or containers
Branches must be bundled (4 feet max length)
Do not place in recycling cart
notes: Yard waste has a separate seasonal collection schedule in Columbus
Check columbus.gov for your pickup dates
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in the recycling cart
Don't use plastic bags for yard waste

materials.name: Diapers and hygiene products
instructions: Roll up and secure with tabs
Place in trash cart
notes: Diapers contain mixed materials and human waste — never recyclable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the recycling cart

materials.name: Soiled or wet paper and cardboard
instructions: Place in trash cart
Grease and food residue ruin paper recycling
notes: Even a small amount of grease can contaminate a batch of recycled paper
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy pizza boxes — tear off the clean top if possible
Don't recycle paper plates or napkins with food

materials.name: Candy wrappers, chip bags, and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash cart
Made of multi-layer film that cannot be recycled
notes: Despite metallic appearance, these are not recyclable aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the metallic sheen is plastic film, not metal

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in trash cart
The plastic polyethylene lining prevents recycling
Cardboard sleeve can be recycled separately
notes: The plastic liner inside paper cups makes them non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
The cardboard sleeve IS recyclable — remove it

materials.name: Plastic utensils and straws
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small for sorting equipment
notes: Even though made of recyclable plastics, utensils are too small for machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — they fall through sorting screens

materials.name: Bubble wrap and air pillows
instructions: Deflate air pillows
Place in trash cart
Some stores accept with plastic bag recycling
notes: Bubble wrap is plastic film — not accepted in Columbus curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling cart

materials.name: Paper towels, napkins, and tissues
instructions: Place in trash cart
Paper fibers too short and contaminated to recycle
notes: Even unused paper towels have fibers too degraded for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in trash cart
Thermal paper contains BPA/BPS — not recyclable
notes: Thermal paper chemicals contaminate recycled paper
commonMistakes: Don't recycle receipts

materials.name: Mirrors, window glass, and ceramics
instructions: Wrap carefully for safety
Place in trash cart
These have different melting points than bottle glass
notes: Only bottle and jar glass is recyclable — not window glass, mirrors, or ceramics
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't confuse drinking glasses with glass bottles

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Return wire hangers to dry cleaners for reuse
notes: Hangers tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put any type of hanger in the recycling cart

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Wax coating prevents recycling
notes: Wax-coated paper cannot be processed at paper recycling mills
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Greasy portions go in trash
If the top is clean, tear it off and recycle it
Greasy bottom always goes in trash
notes: Grease-saturated cardboard cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't recycle the greasy parts

materials.name: Juice pouches and drink pouches
instructions: Place in trash cart
Multi-layer packaging cannot be recycled
notes: Pouches are made of fused plastic and metal layers
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with recyclable cartons

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: If wearable, donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or SWACO Recycling Center
If not wearable, place in trash cart
SWACO accepts clothing for recycling
notes: SWACO Recycling Convenience Center accepts clothing and books
Donation extends the useful life of textiles
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the blue recycling cart
Don't throw away wearable items — donate them

materials.name: Fast food wrappers and containers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Grease contamination makes these non-recyclable
notes: Most fast food packaging is contaminated with food and grease
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy food packaging

materials.name: Incandescent and LED light bulbs
instructions: Wrap in paper or original packaging
Place in trash cart
notes: Incandescent and LED bulbs are not hazardous (unlike CFLs)
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs — CFLs go to SWACO

materials.name: Rubber items
instructions: Place in trash cart
Garden hoses: cut into 3-foot sections
notes: Rubber tangles in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put rubber in recycling — especially hoses

materials.name: Pens, markers, and tape
instructions: Place in trash cart
Mixed materials cannot be separated
notes: Too small and made of bonded materials
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Small appliances
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
Or schedule bulk pickup with Columbus Public Service
Do not place in recycling cart
notes: SWACO accepts appliances for recycling
Small appliances contain recoverable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside carts
Remove batteries if applicable

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup with Columbus Public Service: 311
Or take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center
Appliance retailers often offer haul-away with delivery
notes: Appliances with refrigerants require special handling
SWACO accepts appliances at the Jackson Pike location
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling
Don't attempt to remove refrigerant yourself

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
Home Depot, Lowe's, and Best Buy also accept batteries
Car batteries: return to auto parts store
Do not place in trash or recycling
notes: SWACO specifically accepts batteries
Lithium batteries are a fire hazard in trash trucks
commonMistakes: NEVER put lithium batteries in trash — fire risk
Don't put any batteries in the recycling cart

materials.name: Electronics / e-waste
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
TVs and monitors may have a fee at SWACO
Best Buy accepts most small electronics for free
notes: SWACO specifically lists electronics and TVs as accepted items
Fees may apply for TVs at SWACO
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in curbside carts
Remove personal data from devices before recycling

materials.name: Televisions and monitors
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
Fees may apply for TV recycling
Best Buy accepts TVs up to 32 inches for free
notes: SWACO charges fees for TV/monitor recycling
CRT TVs contain lead and require special handling
commonMistakes: Don't put in curbside carts
Don't break screens — may contain hazardous materials

materials.name: Computers and laptops
instructions: Wipe personal data before recycling
Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center
Best Buy and Staples accept computers
notes: Erase hard drives before recycling for privacy
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Fluorescent bulbs and CFLs
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
Home Depot and Lowe's also accept CFLs
Handle carefully — contains mercury
notes: SWACO specifically lists fluorescent bulbs and CFLs as accepted
Mercury makes these hazardous — do not put in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — mercury is hazardous
Don't break bulbs — mercury vapor is released

materials.name: Paint (latex and oil-based)
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
SWACO accepts both latex and oil-based paint
Keep in original containers with labels
notes: SWACO specifically lists latex and oil-based paint as accepted
Dried latex paint (small amounts with kitty litter) can go in regular trash
commonMistakes: Never pour paint down drains
Don't put liquid paint in regular trash

materials.name: Motor oil and antifreeze
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
Auto parts stores (AutoZone, O'Reilly) also accept used motor oil
Never pour down drains
notes: SWACO specifically accepts motor oil and antifreeze
commonMistakes: Never pour down drains or on the ground
Don't mix motor oil with other fluids

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to SWACO Recycling Convenience Center at 2566 Jackson Pike
Fees may apply
Tire retailers accept old tires when buying new ones
notes: SWACO specifically lists tires as accepted (fees may apply)
Tires are banned from Ohio landfills
commonMistakes: Don't leave tires at the curb
Don't illegally dump tires

materials.name: Clean styrofoam packaging (SWACO only)
instructions: Take clean, white expanded polystyrene packaging to SWACO Recycling Center
Must be clean — no food contamination
Address: 2566 Jackson Pike
notes: SWACO is one of the few places that accepts clean EPS packaging for recycling
This is for packing foam only — not food containers
commonMistakes: Don't bring food-contaminated styrofoam — only clean packing foam
Don't put styrofoam in curbside recycling

materials.name: Medications and pharmaceuticals
instructions: Take to a pharmacy medication take-back program
Columbus Police Division has medication drop-off boxes
Do not flush medications
Do not place in trash or recycling
notes: Flushing medications contaminates water supplies
CVS and Walgreens locations may have take-back programs
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in regular trash where they could be accessed

materials.name: Pesticides, herbicides, and household chemicals
instructions: Do not pour down drains
Take to SWACO or household hazardous waste collection events
Keep in original containers
notes: Check Columbus and Franklin County for HHW collection events
commonMistakes: Never pour chemicals down drains
Don't mix different chemicals

materials.name: Propane tanks and compressed gas
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Large grill tanks: exchange at hardware stores
Small camping cylinders: take to HHW collection
notes: Pressurized containers can explode in compactor trucks
commonMistakes: NEVER place in trash or recycling — explosion risk

materials.name: Sharps and needles
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container
When full, take to an approved drop-off site
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Loose needles endanger sanitation workers and the public
commonMistakes: NEVER put loose needles in trash or recycling
Don't overfill sharps containers

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: absorb with paper towels and trash
Large amounts: store in sealed container and take to a recycling center
Never pour down drains
notes: Cooking oil causes sewer blockages — never pour down drains
commonMistakes: NEVER pour cooking oil down the drain
Don't put liquid oil in recycling

materials.name: Mattresses and large furniture
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup by calling 311
Donate usable items to Goodwill, Habitat ReStore, or Salvation Army
Take to City of Columbus Waste and Reuse Convenience Center at 2100 Alum Creek Drive
notes: Columbus offers bulk pickup and a Waste and Reuse Convenience Center
Donation gives furniture a second life
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Plastic lids and bottle caps
instructions: Leave caps ON plastic bottles when recycling in Columbus
Loose lids without bottles go in trash
notes: Columbus allows caps to stay on bottles
Loose caps fall through sorting screens and should be trashed
commonMistakes: Don't toss loose lids in recycling — they must be on a bottle

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag and staple or fold closed
Place the bag in blue recycling cart
notes: Loose shredded paper jams machinery and blows away
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the cart
Don't use a plastic bag

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in trash cart
Great for home composting if you have a bin
notes: Columbus does not offer curbside composting
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place in trash cart
Good for home composting
notes: No curbside composting in Columbus
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Wrap in newspaper to contain odor
Place in trash cart
Put out on collection day to minimize pest attraction
notes: Meat attracts pests — wrap securely
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't home compost meat — it attracts rodents

recycle: Paper — office, newspaper, magazines, catalogs, mail, envelopes
Cereal boxes and paperboard (flatten, remove liners)
Carton containers — milk, juice, broth (refrigerated and shelf-stable)
Plastic containers — tubs, clamshells, deli containers
trash: Styrofoam (curbside — see SWACO for clean packaging foam)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags — they jam Rumpke sorting machinery
Mirrors, window glass, ceramics, drinking glasses

tips: All recyclables go loose in the blue cart — never bagged
Rinse containers — they don't need to be spotless
Leave caps on plastic bottles in Columbus
When in doubt, throw it out — contamination hurts recycling
Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant — take them to Kroger or Walmart instead
Columbus achieves a 99% recycling recovery rate through Rumpke
SWACO Recycling Center (2566 Jackson Pike) accepts many items not taken curbside
City Waste and Reuse Center at 2100 Alum Creek Drive for furniture and bulk items
Call 311 for bulk pickup scheduling and recycling questions

locations.name: SWACO Recycling Convenience Center
locations.notes: Operated by the Solid Waste Authority of Central Ohio (SWACO). Fees may apply for TVs and tires.

locations.name: City of Columbus Waste and Reuse Convenience Center
Columbus Public Service - Refuse Collection
locations.notes: Call 311 for all refuse and recycling services
